I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans in 
the aggregate amount of up to $100 million to Chattel Constructions Private Limited (Chattel), 
Ganges Green Energy Private Limited (Ganges), Hiraco Renewable Energy Private Limited 
(Hiraco),  Responsive  Sutip  Limited  (Responsive),  Sand  Land  Real  Estate  Private  Limited 
(Sandland), and Ujjawala Power Private Limited (Ujjawala), which are special purpose vehicles 
(SPVs) [confidential information deleted] for the 145 Megawatts Grid-Connected Solar Project in 
India.1 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
1.  Project Identification 
2.  [confidential information deleted] is one of India’s leading solar power developers. The 
project consists of an aggregate 145 megawatts (MW) of grid-connected photovoltaic solar 
power  projects  to  be  installed  by  third  quarter  of  2012  at  six  locations  in  Gujarat  state. 
[confidential information deleted] is developing solar projects domestically and internationally as 
both a developer and developer-operator. The group’s development strategy is to develop a 
total portfolio of 1,500 MW by FY2017. 
 
3.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been engaged with [confidential information] 
deleted]  since  July  2009  in  helping  to  identify  a  group  of  projects  that  have  a  strong 
development impact. [confidential information deleted] has demonstrated its execution strategy 
in commissioning 145 MW in India and 65 MW in Europe, as well as raising equity capital to 
fund  its  project  pipeline  of  135  MW  under  construction  and  over  425  MW  under  early 
development. Successful execution of these initial projects establishes [confidential information 
deleted]  as  an  experienced  developer  of  solar  projects.  ADB’s  approach  in  financing  six 
subprojects, totaling 145 MW of grid-connected solar power generation, is to demonstrate the 
benefits of scale: financing and developing an aggregate set of projects to reduce construction 
mobilization,  financing,  and  management  overhead  costs.  This  approach  maximizes  the 
development impact by enabling a private sector developer to deliver clean energy to the 
regional grid at a sustainable tariff. 
 
2.  Project Design 
4.  The project entails the construction of five 25 MW and one 20 MW solar photovoltaic 
power generation plants, totaling 145 MW, across six locations in Gujarat state. The project 
sites are generally within a 150-kilometer radius of the cities of Ahmedabad, Porbandar, and 
Rajkot and readily accessible by public roads. The annual global horizontal irradiance2 across 
the six subproject sites is estimated to be 2,014–2,062 kilowatt-hours (kWh) per square meter, 
among the strongest in the country. 
 
5.  The project will use a mix of crystalline silicon (105 MW), amorphous silicon (10 MW), 
cadmium  telluride  (20 MW),  and  tandem  junction  amorphous  silicon (10  MW)  photovoltaic 
panels across the six subproject sites on fixed-tilt mounting structures, with one subproject site

(Chattel) employing some single-axis manual tracking structures adapted to site conditions. 
Panels will be supplied by DuPont Apollo (United States), First Solar (United States), Hanwha 
SolarOne (People’s Republic of China), LDK (People’s Republic of China and India), Moser 
Baer (India), and Trina (India). The mixture of panel technologies and suppliers was chosen 
based on optimum cost and schedule delivery criteria. The solar photovoltaic modules are 
guaranteed for a maximum degradation of 10% over the first 10 years of operation and 20% 
over the next 15 years of operation. 
 
6.  The electricity generated from each subproject will be evacuated to existing substations 
through  a  combined  total  of  about  45  kilometers  length  of  66  kilovolts  double-circuit 
transmission lines to be built by Gujarat Electricity Transmission Company. 
 
3.  The Borrowers and Sponsor 
7.  [confidential information deleted],   
 
8.  [confidential information deleted]is developing a number of projects across India as part 
of its group strategy. In addition to the solar projects being developed under the [confidential 
information deleted]is developing over 11,560 MW of conventional and hydroelectric generation 
capacity. 
 
B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
1.  Impact 
9.  The project is designed to promote sustainable economic growth by diversifying India’s 
energy mix through the addition of renewable energy capacity. The development impact of the 
project also includes environmental benefits through more efficient use of indigenous renewable 
energy resources with almost no emission of pollutants or greenhouse gases. In addition, the 
building of the project will help prove the feasibility of utility-scale solar power projects in India 
and the operational performance in a location (Gujarat) where substantial development in solar 
power is planned during 2012–2017. 
 
2.  Outcome 
10.  The  project  will  demonstrate  the  profitability  and  sustainability  of  a  variety  of  solar 
photovoltaic technologies at utility scale on a private generation basis in India by generating 
about 208,000 megawatt-hours3 of clean energy per annum while delivering adequate returns 
for the private sponsor. 
 
3.  Outputs 
11.  Successful implementation of the project will result in the construction and operation of 
utility-scale solar photovoltaic power generation facilities.

C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 
12.  The project supports two of the five core operational areas of ADB’s Strategy 2020: 
infrastructure and environment.4 The project is aligned with ADB’s India country partnership 
strategy (CPS), 2009–2012. One of the four strategy pillars of the CPS is to support inclusive 
and environmentally sustainable growth through continued focus on infrastructure development 
and enhanced focus on renewable energy. The project is consistent with one key outcome 
indicator of the CPS, which targets an addition of at least 70 MW of solar power generation 
through ADB assistance by 2012.5 
 
2.  Consistency with the Energy Policy and the Asia Solar Energy Initiative 
13.  Under ADB’s Energy Policy, ADB’s investments will focus on energy efficiency and 
renewable energy projects, as well as expansion of energy access. The policy states that 
support for renewable energy projects will be prioritized and broadened, with an objective to 
create a framework that makes investing in renewable energy commercially viable. The policy 
envisages that, in the process of facilitating private investments in renewable energy, ADB will 
assume greater (but thoroughly assessed) risks and act as a catalyst for investments that the 
private sector might not otherwise be willing to make.6 
 
14.  The project is directly aligned with ADB’s Asia Solar Energy Initiative, which aims to (i) 
facilitate knowledge sharing for solar power; (ii) help develop, finance, and commission 3,000 
MW of solar power generation capacity by May 2013; and (iii) pilot test innovative financing 
mechanisms  specifically  for  solar  power.  The  initiative  seeks  to  stimulate  solar  power 
development by increasing economies of scale to reduce costs and improve solar energy’s 
competitiveness within the grid and exploiting solar radiation resources to serve fast-growing 
electricity demand. 
 
3.  Consistency with ADB Operations 
15.  The project strongly complements ADB’s current initiatives in solar energy in India. In 
2011, the ADB Board of Directors approved the guarantee facility for Solar Power Generation,7 
which will issue partial credit guarantees in an aggregate principal amount of up to $150 million 
(or its equivalent in Indian rupees or other foreign currency acceptable to ADB), in favor of 
foreign and local commercial financial institutions (partner commercial banks) lending to solar 
power generation projects in India. The facility will support multiple solar generation projects up 
to a maximum capacity of 25 MW under a solar power program with the central or state 
governments.  This  facility  will  catalyze  commercial  lending  and  private  investment  for  the 
smaller solar generation projects, while the project aims to catalyze private investment in larger 
solar  generation  projects  with  a  capacity  greater  than  25  MW.  This  highlights  ADB’s 
multiproduct approach to promote private investment in solar energy and its ability to customize 
based on market needs and associated risks. In a similar manner, the project will promote the

D.  Project Cost and Financing Plan 
16.  The project is estimated to cost Rs18.167 billion. [confidential information deleted] will 
finance each project with equity, long term lending from ADB, and other debt from Nonbank 
Indian financial institutions[confidential information deleted]  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements

Regulatory framework  Gujarat Electricity Regulatory Commission implemented a requirement that all 
distribution  licensees  in  Gujarat  must  purchase  0.5%  of  their  total  electricity 
requirements from solar energy sources during FY2011. This renewable purchase 
obligation increased to 1.0% for FY2012. The Gujarat Urja Vikas  Nigam Ltd 
maintains budgetary means to pay up to a quantum equivalent of the additional 
cost of 1,000 megawatts capacity of solar generation per year above the market 
dispatch rates. 
Implementation period  The anticipated commercial operations date (COD) for all projects is 31 December 
2012. The life of the power purchase agreements is 25 years from COD. 
Construction arrangements

(EPC) contracts with Moser Baer Engineering and Construction Limited (MBECL) 
for (i) procurement and supply of foreign and domestic equipment; and (ii) erection,

validated that the EPC contract is consistent with industry norms and was entered 
into on a commercial arm’s length basis. 
Equipment supplier  Under the EPC contracts, [confidential information deleted] will source the thin film 
and crystalline solar modules from DuPont Apollo (United States), First Solar 
(United States), Hanwha SolarOne (People’s Republic of China), LDK (People’s 
Republic of China and India), Moser Baer (India), and Trina (India). Inverters are 
sourced from Bonfiglioli (Italy) and SMA Electronics (Germany). 
Civil works  Civil works for the balance of the plant (including construction of common facilities, 
control room, and approach road) are subcontracted to local trade contractors. 
Transmission line  Each power generation plant is planned under the Solar Power Policy of the state 
of Gujarat under which the specific provision for power evacuation is made by the 
state government. The power evacuation facilities will be provided by Gujarat 
Energy Transmission Corporation Limited.

GUVNL  to sell 100% of the output of each power plant generation for a period of 
25 years at a fixed rate of Rs11.25 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) for the first 12 years 
and Rs7.5 for the following 13 years. 
Operation and maintenance  Each plant will enter into an operation and maintenance agreement with MBECL 
under terms considered standard practice in the market. The contract is valid for 
10 years with the option to extend based on satisfactory performance. 
Performance monitoring  Key performance indicators will be reported by [confidential information deleted] 
and monitored by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). In addition, during the 
construction phase, ADB will appoint an independent lenders technical advisor to 
monitor progress, attend performance testing, and certify COD.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
17.  The proposed ADB loans in the aggregate amount of up to $100 million to Chattel, 
Ganges,  Hiraco,  Responsive,  Sandland,  and  Ujjawala  to  finance  the  construction  of  each 
subproject  will  be  provided  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  without  government 
guarantee. The ADB loan will have a tenor of up to 15 years, including a grace period of up to 6 
months and will be repaid quarterly. The ADB loan will carry an interest rate as well as other 
fees as approved by ADB’s investment committee. Up to $50 million of the ADB loan will be 
disbursed in Indian rupees via a 15-year cross-currency swap. 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
18.  The proposed transaction merits ADB’s assistance for the following reasons: 
(i)  The project will promote the efficient use of a relatively untapped, indigenous 
energy resource resulting in low-cost, carbon-efficient electricity generation. 
(ii)  The ADB assistance will provide long-term, limited recourse financing, which is 
not readily available for large solar power generation projects in India. This will 
be ADB’s first private sector solar financing in India where the majority of finance 
is from local commercial banks, which, because of the shorter tenors, would not 
have been sufficient to provide the financing needs of the project without the 
longer tenor ADB financing. 
(iii)  ADB participation in the project will help promote global standards for project 
development and due diligence in a nascent sector, thus enabling long-term 
commercial financing for future solar power generation projects in India. 
 
C.  Risks 
19.  Sponsor support.  The loans will have limited recourse to [confidential information 
deleted for debt service obligations of the subprojects.   
 
20.    Tariff risk. The tariff is established in accordance with the Central Electricity Regulatory 
Commission renewable energy tariff regulations of 2009, which are in effect until 31 March 
2013. The applicable tariff is Rs11.25/kWh ($0.20/kWh) for the first 12 years of operation, 
stepping down to Rs7.50/kWh ($0.13/kWh) beyond year 12. This tariff regime is locked in for the 
project if commercial operations date (COD) is achieved by 31 March 2013. Delay risk is well 
mitigated by the advanced stage of completion of the project. 
 
21.   Offtaker risk. The project’s sole offtaker, GUVNL, has a local currency rating of A from 
CARE Ratings. Another domestic ratings agency, CRISIL, in a report prepared for the Forum of 
Regulators, identified that solar RPO purchases in Gujarat will be only 239 million kWh out of 
95,582 million kWh by 2015. This results in an incremental impact (over conventional sources) 
on total power purchase costs of only about Rs0.01/kWh in 2015 and later, indicating low risk of 
offtaker default on RPO tariffs. In the same period, conventional power purchase costs are 
estimated to rise from Rs2.72/kWh to Rs3.36/kWh.  
 
22.  Operation and maintenance (O&M) risk. Each project contracted MBECL to perform 
O&M services to mitigate O&M risk.

6   
 
23.     Foreign exchange risk. Fifty percent of the ADB loan will be denominated in US dollars, 
but the project revenues will be in Indian rupees. The US dollar tranche, however, comprises  
only 12.5% of  total project funding sources. The sponsor guarantees any debt service shortfalls 
caused by foreign exchange movements [confidential information deleted].   
 
24.  Tenor. The ADB loan will have a tenor of up to 15 years. While the term of the energy 
purchase agreement is longer at 25 years, the long tenor of the loan further accentuates the 
technology and foreign exchange risk. These risks are mitigated by the hedging and support 
mechanism  and  the  step-down  in  tariff  after  12  years,  which  reduces  the  risk  of  tariff 
renegotiation by the offtaker. 
 
25.  Implementation and technology risk. Construction risk is substantially mitigated by the 
advanced stage of construction. The module technology is crystalline and amorphous silicon 
and  cadmium  telluride,  which  are  common  technologies  with  a  long  record  of  reliable 
performance. Unique local conditions such as high ambient air temperatures and high levels of 
dust and soiling could impair module performance but performance warranties provided by each 
supplier and conservative forecast of energy yields mitigate this risk.  
 
26.     Related party contracting risk. CRISIL was appointed to independently manage the 
selection  of  EPC  contractor  and  equipment  supplier.  For  each  subproject,  Moser  Baer 
Engineering and Construction Limited (MBECL) had the most competitive bid, with module 
supplies  coming  from  DuPont  Apollo  (United  States),  First  Solar  (United  States),  Hanwha 
SolarOne (People’s Republic of China), LDK (People’s Republic of China and India), Moser 
Baer (India), and Trina (India) [confidential information deleted]. 
 
27.  Interest rate risk. The interest rate for the US dollar-denominated portion of the loan is 
a fixed margin over the applicable 6-month US dollar London interbank offered rate (LIBOR). An 
increase in the interest rate will increase the interest burden on the project and will reduce debt 
service coverage ratios. The loan documentation will specify interest rate hedging strategies to 
mitigate this risk. Further, the sensitivity of the project cash flows to changes in the interest rate 
is low because of fixed interest rate Indian rupee loans from the swapped component of the 
ADB loan and other domestic senior lenders. 
 
 
IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
28.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified 
category  B  for  environment,  and  category  C  for  involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous 
peoples. The potential environmental and social impacts and risks of the project have been 
identified and effective measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the adverse 
impacts are incorporated in the safeguard reports and plans. The institutional capacity and 
commitment of each project company to manage the project’s social and environmental impacts 
and risks are deemed adequate. Information disclosure and consultations with affected people 
were conducted in accordance with ADB requirements and a grievance redress mechanism is in 
place.9 [confidential information deleted] will ensure that the project is in compliance with 
                                                 
9  Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy; Safeguards and Social Dimensions Summary (accessible from 
the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

7
applicable national laws and regulations and will implement and monitor measures to manage 
impacts and risks, all in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements. 
 
29.   Measures to benefit women or facilitate their involvement in construction and operation 
of the project have been incorporated in the project design in accordance with ADB’s Policy on 
Gender  and  Development  (1998).  The  project  companies  will  comply  with  ADB’s  Social 
Protection Strategy and report regularly to ADB on their compliance (including contractors) with 
national  labor  laws  and  adherence  to  internationally  recognized  core  labor  standards.10 
Information disclosure and consultations with affected people were conducted in accordance 
with ADB requirements (footnote 14). 
 
30.  The project companies will comply with ADB’s Social Protection Strategy and report 
regularly  to  ADB  on  their  compliance  (including  contractors)  with  national  labor  laws  and 
adherence  to  internationally  recognized  core  labor  standards  (footnote  15).  Each  project 
company has formulated its own corporate human resources policy embodying the gender-
related core labor standards. Information disclosure and consultations with affected people were 
conducted in accordance with ADB requirements (footnote 14). 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
31.  [confidential information deleted] was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best 
international practice relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of 
terrorism.  ADB  will  ensure  that  the  loan  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions 
prohibiting corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB 
in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations  
32.  The proposed loan is within the medium-term country, industry, group, and single project 
exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D.  Assurances 
33.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (the 
Charter),11 the Government of India will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to the 
proposed assistance to [confidential information deleted]. ADB will enter into suitable finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the Board. 
 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
34.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loans in the 
aggregate amount of up to $100,000,000 to Chattel Constructions Private Limited, Ganges 
Green Energy Private Limited, Hiraco Renewable Energy Private Limited, Responsive Sutip 
Limited, Sand Land Real Estate Private Limited, and Ujjawala Power Private Limited, each a 
special  purpose  vehicle  [confidential  information  deleted],  for  the  145  Megawatts  Grid-
Connected Solar Project in India from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with such terms and
